title: Did the Native Americans have IQs that were close to that of the European settlers? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: This is a bit of a trick question because our concept of IQ wasn’t really pertinent to either group. You’d need to come up with some other measurement for general intelligence. And then you’d have to decide what kinds of intelligence would have been more or less helpful for either group at that time. Then there’s a separate issue related to group intelligence… how well did individuals work together? The Europeans tended to be short-sighted as far as native peoples went. It’s hard to take advantage of people without first persuading yourself they deserve to be taken advantage of, either because of your superiority in some way or because they’re not fully human in your eyes. The biggest mistake Native Americans made was failing to understand just how many Europeans would come. We’ve seen lots of invasions throughout history, but nothing compares to the scale of what happened in the Americas. The Europeans just kept coming… and coming—and they all carried microbes. They knew more about how pathogens killed and took advantage of that knowledge. The only comparable wipe out was when people first crossed into the Americas… and promptly wiped out whole species. Yeah. People can be pretty devastating. Here’s the interesting bit for me: when you realize 90 percent of American natives died in this unbelievable invasion… what does that mean about the 10 percent who survived? Pretty tough cookies, I’m thinking. Tough and smart. In case you haven’t looked, the invasion isn’t over. We’ve treated native Americans shamefully and we’ve done very little to make amends. It’s a stupidity on our part. Why aren’t we able to see how much benefit such people could be for the rest of us? Why aren’t we providing support? Too many are still hanging on to the idiotic notion that they’re not quite as human as us.

Completely unknown and unknowable.  Even with the (probably scarce,  as it's an academically untouchable area practically)  current data on such things,  there is little that I have ever read of American indigenous peoples' IQ's.   Most of the controversial writings related to this topic have focused primarily on the alleged general trend of IQ differences (from lesser-to-greater)  between, respectively,  black Africans and descendants abroad,  Caucasians (not restricted to solely Europeans but including Middle Easterners as well),   Jewish Caucasians,  and East (though not necessarily southeast) Asians.   With the East Asians such as Chinese, Japanese, Koreans, appearing to come out ahead of all of the others in general, and Jewish Europeans excelling in certain areas where non-Jewish Europeans may not necessarily.   Of course if observable exceptions exist (they must) then it's all disprovable anyway and,  beyond that,  IQ score in and of itself need not be the sole indicator of intelligence.  Nor do we know for sure that intelligence is unchangeable throughout one's entire life (though there probably is a general baseline area from around which a person will probably not deviate greatly).   I personally think intelligence is an at least partly heritable trait, though one that can certainly be molded for better or worse by environmental and other factors.  Also, by today's standards, many of the rank-and-file Europeans who poured into and colonized the Americas hundreds of years ago (whether the English, the Spanish,  Portuguese,  French,  & whoever else) would probably appear -- and score -- markedly dumber than a counterpart with the same ethnic background today.   There are many factors at play.   Education,  nutrition,  general access to knowledge and generally held knowledge about everything from medicine to astronomy to geography.  To an extent then, almost any 21st century person is likely 'smarter' than an average person -- note,  average person -- from the 16th or 17th century.

You will get a lot of misleading answers to this question, largely because the entire subject of genetics and IQ has been highly politicized. The question is best resolved by comparison of carefully administered test results based on the genetic background of the individuals that are tested. There are also quite a few different “native American” groups, ranging from forest-dwellers of the Amazon to the Inca, Maya, Aztec, Navaho, Iroquian tribes, Arctic tribes, etc. With enough sampling you would probably find statistically significant differences between any of these, with respect to the population mean. Around the population mean, of course, there is a lot of variation. Remember that about half of the Europeans would have an IQ below 100, half above. So you could find most likely find some people in a population with a lower mean IQ that have a higher IQ than some people in a population with a higher mean IQ. IQ is not a population trait, but mean IQ is. Biologists have no problem with the measurement of population traits and inter-population variation in those traits, but a lot of people who control the social departments and administration of universities have a vested interest in the “blank slate” concept that such variation does not exist. These people will always tell you that IQ measurements are flawed, unless they reveal the “truth” that they espouse. So the first question for YOU to answer is simply this: Are you looking for the truth, or just trying to find a supporting opinion?

For the reasons others have listed, we cannot know the IQ of the Native Americans, but we can know that, divorced from artificial numbers determined by culturally-biased tests, they had the same range of intelligence within their population as the European settlers. There were very smart Native American, and very smart Europeans. In both cases, they were few. There was a large number of both groups that had average intelligence. There was another small number of both groups that were intellectually impaired. Over and over again, we need to remind ourselves that there is no difference in the range of intellectual development by “race.” Native Americans may have used their intelligence differently to deal with a different life experience, but the smart ones still found solutions more quickly than most of the others, and the impaired ones needed more help than the others. Where a European might use his compass and sextant to determine his position, a Native American would use his knowledge of flora and fauna for the same purpose. The difference would be that the Native American would be able to use his insight immediately, but the European would have to plot his numbers on a map, and hope the map was accurate.

We don’t have the people and we don’t have records of the IQ tests they didn't take. We do have some contemporary accounts. Indians, by those accounts, picked up English pretty quickly. And later, Spanish. Pocahontas and La Malinche are famous. Jefferson, no egalitarian, concluded on the basis of this evidence and the many other accounts he received that we don’t normally read about or that were never written down that the people of the tribes of North America that his time had run into, the Cherokee, the Iroquois, etc. were fully equal to Europeans in native wit. The Cherokee developed their own alphabet and wrote and published in it. The founder of all that first taught his daughter, and she picked it up in a jiffy. None of this can be taken as definitive but you always want to at least look at what the people of the day concluded, especially if they concluded they were not “superior”.

The culture of the native Americans may have been non-technological, but this doesn't mean that the people were incapable of advanced thought.They were/are people, and if raised and educated in a science-steeped environment, they will do as well as anybody else (as a group). If you are raised in an agrarian agricultural society, you will probably excel in farming and farm methods. If you are raised in a sea-faring culture and environment, you will probably be good seamen. If raised in a warlike, aggressive... well, you get the idea.

Using what method to test? IQ test are based on an individual having a certain amount "common knowledge"  Sustenance based cultures especially without a written language did not/do not necessarily share this type of knowledge, therefore it is impossible to measure their intelligence using this means. Unfortunately, tests were administered anyways, and the results were always poor, but know one considered (or cared) that these results were skewed. Inuit have the highest social intelligence of any other people I have come across. European people are generally completely lost in close inuit group presence, because we lack somewhat, in this area.  There are different types of intelligence that are generally suited to ones environment. I think you would find on a level playing field, all groups of people come out about the same overall.

They did.  Among the brightest of the aboriginals were the Cherokee and the Seminole.   The Cherokee were realistic.  They understood full well that white culture was going to triumph so they did their level best to accomodate it and even adapt it.  Little good this  that do them.  That Stone Killer Andrew Jackson sent the Cherokee on the Trail of Tears.  the American version of the Bataan Death March.

IQ scores are 20th Century culturally-based tests designed by advocates of eugenics to identify children with special educational needs and to justify selective human breeding and immigration restrictions. They didn’t exist during the settlement of the Americas and would not have applied to either the Amerindians or the European settlers who came from nations with different customs and educational practices. Native Indians tended to be more verbally proficient and articulate in their native tongues than Europeans in theirs, but pre-1600 Amerindians had no written language traditions and absolutely no customs that involved the application of the scientific method such as mathematics, engineering, chemistry or physics. They could, however, survive in harsh environmental circumstances and withstand physical challenges foreign to all Europeans.

Growing up Yakama and Nez Perce I was told as a child Intelligence Varied Tribe to Tribe, Such as The Obvious, Farming Tribes and Some Coastal were more Sophisticated and Literate than the ones whose Culture Revolved Around Tradition,Hunting and Gathering an such.

The answer is almost certainly 'no', because this is really a non-question.  The culture and environment of the Native Americans was radically different from that of the European settlers, so any kind of comparative test of thinking powers would have yielded very different results among the two populations, simply because they thought in very different ways.

My common sense says that people who are building complex structures like cathedrals are probably more intelligent than people who are only able to build small cabins. People who are building real ocean ships (and cross the ocean) are more intelligent than people who are only building then a low-tech canoe. I think you got your answer. But being more intelligent as a person or as an ethnical group does not make you by definition superior in other fields of human behavior. To say it in a metaphor: a shepherd dog and a poodle dog are both dogs but with different qualities and both are OK.

If you could come up with an IQ test that was not culturally biased in favor of the culture of the person preparing the test, which is probably impossible, you would find that all humans, being of the same species of all other humans, would have the same range of actual problem solving intelligence. You have only to see how every human civilization, no matter how isolated, has adapted their environment to meet rheir needs. The “advanced societies” are merely the ones which more access to other societies and their accomplishments, which they have adopted. I have been DNA tested, and was amazed at the breadth of geography represented in my makeup.

Higher, I would say. Mine is close to 140 and I’m rather average. It all depends on how well one understands life. They’re reevaluating IQ in a lot of people around the world on that. If someone only gets thru Middle School, how can he or she know higher math? For that matter, a lot of freshmen at college are taking reading, notes, and math courses their first year. What’s happened to the education system? Native Americans learn to survive. The best way to survive in the outside world is keep your mouth shut. Like the Cherokee said in song, watch, look, and listen, baby. Did you know Elvis Presley was Cherokee?

FWIW, according to Jared Diamond the average level of smarts amongst hunter-gatherers is higher than amongst people of technologically advanced societies. If you think for a moment about Darwin, one can imagine why this might be so.

You could say yes, they had exactly the same IQs as the European settlers, because there was no such thing as an IQ test at the time. If you're asking were the Indigenous Peoples any less intelligent than the settlers, no they were no less intelligent, and were probably actually MORE intelligent than the majority of the settlers.

Who knows; even if IQ testing was done back, say 600 years ago by Europeans (which, of course, they were not) the test given would have been highly ethnocentric and therefore horribly flawed. Only if an IQ test reflecting each culture could be conducted would there by any meaningful data that could be derived from it. However, if that were possible, my assumption would be that there would be little if any difference between the two. Why? Because we are all from the same initial gene pool. We are all humans.
You don't survive in a hostile environment with limited technology by being dim-witted.

There were no IQ tests back then, and studies have shown that IQ in populations can change over time due to various factors. You’ll have to extrapolate from things like comparisons to modern IQ data and their level of civilization at the time of discovery.
That would depend on the European or Native American you could have tested. But IQ Tests didn't exist then.
S
